We will use the notation \ast \colon S\times S\to S to denote a binary operation on a set S that sends the pair (x,y) to x\ast y. Recall that a binary operation \ast is associative means that x\ast(y\ast z)= (x\ast y)\ast z for all x,y,z\in S. associative binary operation
Group group
A group is a set G, together with a binary operation \ast\colon G\times G \to G with the following properties.
The operation \ast is associative.
There exists an element e in G, called an identity element, such that e\ast g=g\ast e=g for all g\in G.
For every g\in G, there exists an element h\in G, called an inverse element for g, such that g\ast h=h \ast g=e.
Immediate consequences of the definition of group
Let G be a group. The element e in the second property of is unique. Given g\in G, the element h in the third property of is unique.
See and .
Further notation and vocabulary related to the definition of group
Let G be a group. By , we may speak of an identity element as the identity element for G. groupidentity element Given g\in G, we may refer to an inverse element for g as the inverse of g, and we write g^{-1} to denote this element. groupinverse of a group element In practice, we often suppress the operator \ast, and simply write gh to denote g\ast h. For k\geq 1, we write g^k to denote \underbrace{g\ast g\ast \cdots \ast g}_{k \text{ factors}} and we write g^{-k} to denote \underbrace{g^{-1}\ast g^{-1}\ast \cdots \ast g^{-1}}_{k \text{ factors}}.
In some cases, such as the group of integers, the group operation is naturally called addition. In such cases, we write a+b to denote a\ast b, we write -a to denote the inverse of a, and we write ka to denote \underbrace{a+ a+ \cdots +a}_{k \text{ summands}}. This additive notation is only used if the group operation is commutative. A group with a commutative operation is called abelian. groupabelian abelian

statement.p: A subset H of a group G is called a subgroup of G if H is itself a group under the group operation of G. We write H\leq G to indicate that H is a subgroup of G. A (left) coset of a subgroup H of G is a set of the form gH := \{gh \colon h\in H\}. The set of all cosets of H is denoted G/H. G/H := \{gH\colon g\in G\}

Consider D_4 as described in . D_4=\{R_0,R_{1/4},R_{1/2},R_{3/4},F_H,F_V,F_D,F_{D'}\}
Is the subset \{R_0,R_{1/4},R_{1/2},R_{3/4}\} of rotations a subgroup of D_4? Why or why not? Yes. The composition of any two rotations is a rotation, and every rotation has an inverse that is also a rotation.
Is the subset \{F_H,F_V,F_D,F_{D'}\} of reflections a subgroup of D_4? Why or why not? No. Just observe that F_H^2=R_0 is not a reflection. The group operation on D_4 does not restrict properly to the subset of reflections.

Let G be a group and let H be a subgroup of G. The set G/H of cosets of H is a partition of G.
